CAPTION FIG1.png: 'Figure 1: Sequence conservation and occurrence of THATCH domains. **(a)** An alignment of representative THATCH domains from diverse organisms. _Magenta_, invariant residues; gold, residues with a conservation index of 5 or greater as determined by _AL_SCRIPT58. The secondary structure of the human HIP1R THATCH core is shown above the alignment: cyan, a-helices; blue, 310-helical segments; orange, connecting loops. Boundaries of the THATCH domain and are as well as the tail-related region are indicated. Bures below the secondary structure marked L.W, E and \\(Q\\) denote the position of the initial conserved residue in each of four clustered blocks of conservation in the region originally generated as the l/UWEQ module on the basis of sequence comparisons51,52, Numbering is from human HIP1R (HIP1Rh _H_). Suffixes in sequence names indicate species, as follows: human, _Homo sapiens_; mouse, _Mus musculus_; rat, _Ratus nongeticus_; worm, _Cenenorhabditis elegans_; _fly_, _Decosophila melanogaster_; mosquito, _Anagahales gambluc_; ca, _Candida albicans_; sc, _Saccharomyces cerevisiae_; _Saccharomyces pombe_; _Vl_, _Varoxin jinylclic_; \\(n\\), _Nevoxanoxan_; **(b)** Schematic of HIP1R/Sla2p family and cytoskeletal proteins containing THATCH domains. Slabres separate alternate names for the same protein. Labels denote the following: DC, coiled coil, FERM, hard 4.1-lezrin/radixin/moesin domain; DPF and FXDMF, AP-2-binding motifs; clathrin box, LLDLQ-type motif involved in clathrin binding; clathrin assembly, region involved in clathrin light-chain binding and clathrin assembly. Gray, sequence-conserved C-terminal latch removed by proteolysis. THATCH core boundaries established by N-terminal sequencing and mass spectrometry are indicated (see Methods).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG2.png: 'Figure 2: Crystal structure of the H\\({}^{1}\\)B 1R THATCH dermain care. (a) Stereo view of experimental electron density from the 2.1-A density-modified M\\(\\Omega\\) map centered at 1.5 \\(\\sigma\\) with the final refined model superimposed. (b) Helical-wheel representation of the H\\({}^{1}\\)P1R THATCH core (\\(3.6\\) residues per turn). Circles are calered by residue progeny (blank, hrdrophatic; blue, hexic; red, acidic; green, polar) with fill colors corresponding to sequence conservation among THATCH domains as in Figure 1a. (c) HIP1R THATCH core calered according to secondary structure as in Figure 1a. This and other ribbon diagrams were prepared using RiBBONS(r). Topology diagrams of THATCH core is shown below. Solid and dashed lines represent corrective loops on opposite ends of the hexes. (d,e) Optimal overlaps of THATCH core with vinculin (r)(PDB entry 1QKR; 102 residues aligned with r.m.s. deviation of 4.7) and apolipoprotein III(r)(PDB entry 1AEP; 116 residues aligned with r.m.s. deviation of 3.7), as determined by Dali(r).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG3.png: 'Figure 3: HIP1R THATCH core binds F-actin to a lesser extent than HIP1R THATCH owing to loss of oligomerization through the THATCH domain latch. (**a**) F-actin coacedientation assays with HIP1R THATCH, core, latch and GST-HIP1R core constructs (4 mg) performed as tridations with increasing amounts of F-actin. The samples were centrifuged and the supernatant (S) and pellet (P) fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE with Coomassie staining. The panels show a representative experiment. (**b**) F-actin coacedientation assays with GST-HIP1R core and GST alone (8 mg), performed with or without 20 mg of actin. The panels show a representative experiment. (**c**) Percentage of the various proteins bound to F-actin (means +- s.e. from four independent experiments). Inset shows a schematic representation of the various HIP1R THATCH domain constructs used in F-actin binding assays. (**d**) Ed filtration chromatography indicates the THATCH domain latch can mediate homodimerization. HIP1 and HIP1R THATCH either at calibrated volumes consistent with elongated dimeric species, whereas core constructs elute at volumes consistent with monomers. The mean elution volumes for stacked proteins used to calibrate the column is also shown along with their linear fit versus _Ig_/molecular weight. (**e**) SPR analysis of HIP1R THATCH and HIP1R core binding to F-actin immobilized on a CMS chip. Shown are the response curves for a typical HIP1R THATCH titration experiment (cyan) as well as for HIP1R core (red) and GST-HIP1R core (orange) at their highest concentrations (200 μM). The response values used were corrected by subtraction of response curves of the same samples fitted over a G-actin-coupled flow cell. Inset shows a schematic representation of the experimental setup. (**f**) Equilibrium analysis of HIP1R THATCH binding to F-actin. \\(R_{\\text{eq}}\\) values from the data in **e** are plotted against analyte concentration with a nonlinear fit superimposed. Inset shows a Scatchard plot of the same data.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG4.png: 'Figure 4: Surface analysis of the HIP1R THATCH core reveals a potential F-actin-binding surface. (**a**) Ribbon diagram of the HIP1R THATCH core to give orientation. (**b**) Surface mapping of sequence conservation as colored and calculated in **Figure 1a.** Residues targeted for mutation are labeled with the mutation in bold. (**c**) Electrostatic surface potential of the HIP1R THATCH core as calculated by GRASPED. Surface colors are contoured from red (\\(\\sim\\)10 kT) to blue (+10 kT). (**d**) Surface mapping of hydrophobic atoms (carbon and sulfur; green).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG5.png: 'Figure 5: Mutational analysis of the HIP1R THATCH domain reveals an F-actin-binding surface. (**a**) SPR analysis of HIP1R THATCH constructs binding to F-actin immobilized on a CME chip. Shown are the response curves of wild-type (WT) HIP1R THATCH and of the HIP1R THATCH mutants V923D, K922D, A875D, G871D and 922-Lys-Lys-Lys-Lys-924\\(-\\)922-Jep-Asp-Asp-924 (KVK-DDD) A875D at 100 ml, all others at 200 ml/h in interaction with F-actin. The response values plotted were corrected by subtraction of response curves of the same samples flowed over a G-actin-coupled flow cell. (**b**) Representative Coomassie-stained gel of the F-actin cosedimentation assays for WT HIP1R THATCH and HIP1R THATCH KK\\(-\\)DDD. (**c**) Plot of F-actin cosedimentation data comparing WT HIP1R THATCH with the S874D, K922D and KVK\\(-\\)DDD variants. The percentages of the various proteins bound to actin quantitated from scanned Coomassie-stained gels (means +-5.6 from four independent experiments) are graphed. (**d**) Summary of the results from F-actin-binding assays by SPR and cosedimentation. Dissociation constant (\\(K_{d}\\)) and associated e.e. listed for each SPR study is derived from nonlinear fits to equilibrium data as in **Figure 3**. ND, not determined; asterisk, no binding detectable at the highest concentrations. In cosedimentation data summaries, the number of plus signs (+) indicates the relative strength of binding and a minus (-) indicates very little or no binding observed. (**e**) Ribbon diagram highlighting the residues targeted by mutagenesis. Residues are color coded according to their relative F-actin-binding ability as assessed by cosedimentation: green, +++; yellow, +; red, +; (**f**) Schematic delineating intermolecular interactions involving the HIP1-HIP1R heterodimer and the endocytic machinery. Inset shows a conceptual schematic of THATCH domain interaction with F-actin. Magenta patch represents the sequence-conserved surface shown by mutagenesis to affect F-actin binding. Latch-mediated interactions need not be only between lactates (as depicted in the illustration), but rather could include domain-scanning types of interactions.\n\n'
